sen.j: 来迎院（らいごういん）は京都市東山区にある真言宗泉涌寺派に属する仏教寺院。
sen.e: Raigo-in Temple (Higashiyama Ward, Kyoto City) is a Buddhist temple of the Sennyu-ji school of the Shingon Sect.
Raigo-in Temple (Higashiyama Ward, Kyoto City) is a Buddhist temple of the Sennyu-ji school of the Shingon Sect.
Raigo-in Temple (Higashiyama Ward, Kyoto City) is a Buddhist temple of the Sennyu-ji school of the Shingon Sect.

sen.j: 山号は明応山。
sen.e: Its sango (literally, "mountain name", the title prefixed to the name of a Buddhist temple) is Mt. Meio.
Its sango (literally, "mountain name", the title prefixed to the name of a Buddhist temple) is Mt. Meio.
Its sango (literally, "mountain name", the title prefixed to the name of a Buddhist temple) is Mt. Meio.

sen.j: 本尊は阿弥陀如来。
sen.e: Its principle image is Amida Nyorai (Amitabha Tathagatae).
Its principle image is Amida Nyorai (Amitabha Tathagatae).
Its principle image is Amida Nyorai (Amitabha Tathagatae).

sen.j: 泉涌寺の塔頭。
sen.e: This temple is a chuto (sub-temple founded, especially one to commemorate the death of a high priest) of Sennyu-ji Temple.
This temple is a chuto (sub-temple founded to commemorate the death of a high priest) of Sennyu-ji Temple.
This temple is a chuto (sub-temple founded to commemorate the death of a high priest) of Sennyu-ji Temple.

sen.j: 禁裏御菩提所泉涌寺別当、御寺（みてら）別当来迎院とも称する（「御寺」とは泉涌寺のこと）。
sen.e: This temple is called "Kinri Gobodaisho Sennyu-ji Betto" (the steward of Sennyu-ji Temple, the imperial family's temple) or "Mitera Betto Raigo-in" (Raigo-in, the steward of the honorable temple (i.e., Sennyu-ji Temple).

This temple is called "Kinri Gobodaisho Sennyu-ji Betto" (the steward of Sennyu-ji Temple, the imperial family's temple) or "Mitera Betto Raigo-in" (Raigo-in, the steward of the honorable temple (i.e., Sennyu-ji Temple).

This temple is called Kinri Gobodaisho Sennyu-ji Betto (the steward of Sennyu-ji Temple, the imperial family's temple) or Mitera Betto Raigo-in (Raigo-in, the steward of the honorable temple (i.e., Sennyu-ji Temple)).

sen.j: 歴史
sen.e: Its history
Its history
History

sen.j: 寺伝によれば、空海（弘法大師）が806年（大同 (日本)元年）に唐（中国）で感得した荒神像を安置して来迎院を開創したとされる。
sen.e: According to a temple legend, Raigo-in Temple was built by Kukai (Kobo daishi, one of the best known and most beloved Buddhist saints in Japan, founder of the Shingon ("True Word") school of Buddhism) in 806 by enshrining the statue of Kojin (god of a cooking stove) he had happened to obtain in Tang (China).
sen.cmt: 「感得」をここでは、思いがけずに手に入ったという意味に介しています。
sen.e: According to a temple legend, Raigo-in Temple was built by Kukai (Kobo daishi, one of the best known and most beloved Buddhist saints in Japan, founder of the Shingon ("True Word") school of Buddhism) in 806 by enshrining the statue of Kojin (god of a cooking stove) he had happened to obtain in Tang (China).

According to a temple legend, Raigo-in Temple was built by Kukai (Kobo daishi, one of the best known and most beloved Buddhist saints in Japan, founder of the Shingon ("True Word") school of Buddhism) in 806 by enshrining the statue of Kojin (god of a cooking stove) he had happened to obtain in Tang (China).

sen.j: それから数百年後、泉涌寺第4世月翁律師が藤原信房の帰依を受け、来迎院の諸堂を整備したが、文明の乱の兵火により炎上し、荒廃した。
sen.e: Hundreds of years later, FUJIWARA no Nobufusa, who entered the priesthood under the 4th head priest of Sennyu-ji Temple, Getsuo Ritsushi, built various halls of Raigo-in Temple, but they were destroyed by fire in the Bunmei Disturbance, leaving the temple abandoned.

Hundreds of years later, FUJIWARA no Nobufusa, who entered the priesthood under the 4th head priest of Sennyu-ji Temple, Getsuo Ritsushi, built various halls at Raigo-in Temple, but they were destroyed by fire in the Bunmei Disturbance, leaving the temple abandoned.

Hundreds of years later, FUJIWARA no Nobufusa, who entered the priesthood under the 4th head priest of Sennyu-ji Temple, Getsuo Ritsushi, built various halls at Raigo-in Temple, but they were destroyed by fire in the Bunmei Disturbance, leaving the temple abandoned.

sen.j: その後、1577年（天正5年）、中興の祖・舜甫長老が織田信長より50石を受け、1597年（慶長2年）には前田利家が諸堂の再建を行い、徳川家も別朱印状と100石あまりを与えられ、経済的な基盤も整い、ようやく復興を果たした。
sen.e: Syunsuke choro (a senior priest of the temple, credited for restoring it) received 50 koku (measure of volume) of rice from Nobunaga ODA in 1577, had its halls repaired by Toshiie MAEDA (one of the leading generals of Oda Nobunaga, who became the lord of Kaga Domain, the wealthiest domain in the Edo period) in 1597, and was also given 100 koku of rice and a shuinjo (shogunate license to trade) by Ieyasu TOKUGAWA (the founder of the Tokugawa shogunate); after all these years, the temple was finally revived with a solid financial base.

Shunsuke Choro (a senior priest of the temple, credited for restoring it) received 50 koku (measure of volume) of rice from Nobunaga Oda in 1577, had its halls repaired by Toshiie Maeda (one of the leading generals of Nobunaga Oda, who became the lord of Kaga Domain, the wealthiest domain in the Edo period) in 1597, and was also given 100 koku of rice and a shuinjo (shogunate license to trade) by Ieyasu Tokugawa (the founder of the Tokugawa shogunate), and after all these years, the temple was finally revived with a solid financial base.

Shunsuke Choro (a senior priest of the temple, credited for restoring it) received 50 koku (measure of volume) of rice from Nobunaga ODA in 1577, had its halls repaired by Toshiie MAEDA (one of the leading generals of Nobunaga ODA, who became the lord of Kaga Domain, the wealthiest domain in the Edo period) in 1597, and was also given 100 koku of rice and a shuinjo (shogunate license to trade) by Ieyasu TOKUGAWA (the founder of the Tokugawa shogunate), and after all these years, the temple was finally revived with a solid financial base.

sen.j: 朝廷では、安産の勅願所として信仰を集め、禁裏御菩提所の別当になった。
sen.e: The temple was worshipped by the imperial family as the place to pray for easy delivery, and became betto (steward) that administered the imperial family's temples.
The temple was worshipped by the imperial family as the place to pray for easy delivery, and became betto (steward) that administered the imperial family's temples.
The temple was worshipped by the imperial family as the place to pray for easy delivery, and became betto (steward) that administered the imperial family's temples.

sen.j: 1701年（元禄14年）、大石良雄は赤穂を退去後、外戚にあたる当時の来迎院長老を頼り、寺請証文を受け山科に居を構えた。
sen.e: In 1701, Yoshio OISHI (the chief retainer of Ako Domain and the head of Ako roshi (ex-Ako saumurai, who left their domain to take revenge for their lord who had been forced to commit ritual suicide by disembowelment)) visited one of his maternal relatives, who was a senior priest of this temple, after leaving Ako, to have a Terauke shomon (certificate of a Buddhist temple) issued, and settled in Yamashina (a suburb of Kyoto).

In 1701, Yoshio OISHI (the chief retainer of Ako Domain and the head of Ako roshi (ex-Ako saumurai, who left their domain to take revenge for their lord who had been forced to commit ritual suicide by disembowelment)) visited one of his maternal relatives, who was a senior priest of this temple, after leaving Ako, to have a Terauke shomon (certificate of a Buddhist temple) issued, and settled in Yamashina (a suburb of Kyoto).

In 1701, Yoshio OISHI (the chief retainer of Ako Domain and the head of Ako roshi (ex-Ako samurai, who left their domain to take revenge for their lord who had been forced to commit ritual suicide by disembowelment)) visited one of his maternal relatives, who was a senior priest of this temple, after leaving Ako, to have a Terauke shomon (certificate of a Buddhist temple) issued, and settled in Yamashina (a suburb of Kyoto).

sen.j: 来迎院の檀家となった。
sen.e: He became a danka (supporter) of Raigo-in Temple.
He became a danka (supporter) of Raigo-in Temple.
He became a danka (supporter) of Raigo-in Temple.

sen.j: 大石良雄は来迎院の林泉を好み、書院と茶席含翆軒を設けた。
sen.e: Yoshio OISHI, who loved the garden of Raigo-in Temple, which was designed with trees and fountains, built a shoin (drawing room) and a chaseki (tea ceremony room) called "Gansuiken".
Yoshio OISHI, who loved the garden of Raigo-in Temple, which was designed with trees and fountains, built a shoin (drawing room) and a chaseki (tea ceremony room) called "Gansuiken".
Yoshio OISHI, who loved the garden of Raigo-in Temple, which was designed with trees and fountains, built a shoin (drawing room) and a chaseki (tea ceremony room) called Gansuiken.

sen.j: 含翆軒は、弘法大師が独鈷を用いて掘られて湧水した名水「独鈷水」があるのを喜んで設けたと伝えられている。
sen.e: According to a legend, he was so impressed with the temple's fine spring water, called "Tokko water", which had been dug by Kobo Daishi using Tokko (a religious tool like a short stick), that he built Gansuiken.

According to a legend, he was so impressed with the temple's fine spring water, called "Tokko water", which had been dug by Kobo Daishi using Tokko (a religious tool like a short stick), that he built Gansuiken.

According to a legend, he was so impressed with the temple's fine spring water, called 'Tokko water', which had been dug by Kobo Daishi using Tokko (a religious tool like a short stick), that he built Gansuiken.

sen.j: また、念持仏として大石良雄が、勝軍地蔵菩薩を信仰していたとされ、京阪にいる元赤穂藩の同士と密議を行ったと伝えられる。
sen.e: Yoshio OISHI is believed to have worshipped Shogun Jizo Bosatsu (Ksitigarbha of winning the battle) as his nenjibutsu (a small statue of Buddha kept beside the person), and to have communicated with his ex-Ako warriors in Kyoto or Osaka.

Yoshio OISHI is believed to have worshipped Shogun Jizo Bosatsu (Ksitigarbha of winning the battle) as his nenjibutsu (a small statue of Buddha kept beside the person), and to have communicated with his ex-Ako warriors in Kyoto or Osaka.

Yoshio OISHI is believed to have worshipped Shogun Jizo Bosatsu (Ksitigarbha of winning the battle) as his nenjibutsu (a small statue of Buddha kept beside the person), and to have communicated with his ex-Ako warriors in Kyoto or Osaka.

sen.j: 来迎院に安置の三宝大荒神像は空海（弘法大師）の作と伝えられる（実際の制作は鎌倉時代）。
sen.e: The statue of Sanpo Daikojin (literally, the great god of a cooking stove, or the god of three treasures) enshrined in Raigo-in is said to have been engraved by Kukai (Kobo daishi) (actually, the statue was made in the Kamakura period).
sen.cmt: 「三宝大荒神像」の英訳ですが、Termsによれば、三宝大荒神像→the statue of Sanpo Daikojin (literally, the great god of a cooking stove of three treasures) となっておりますが、「三宝」をof three treasuresとすると、逆に意味がわからなくなりますので、訳を変えました。また、大荒神像の「三宝」の意味は、いろいろな解釈があるようです。
sen.e: The statue of Sanpo Daikojin (literally, the great god of a cooking stove, or the god of three treasures) enshrined in Raigo-in is said to have been engraved by Kukai (Kobo daishi) (actually, the statue was made in the Kamakura period).

The statue of Sanpo Daikojin (literally, the great god of a cooking stove, or the god of three treasures) enshrined in Raigo-in is said to have been engraved by Kukai (Kobo daishi) (actually, the statue was made in the Kamakura period).

sen.j: 「ゆな荒神」とも称され、衣食住の3つの宝を授ける広福天王守宅神であるが安産の御利益もあるとされて信仰を集めている。
sen.e: This deity is also called "Yuna Kojin", who is Kofuku Tenno Shutakushin (home guardian) believed to give people the three treasures of "i shoku jyu" (food, clothing & shelter) as well as to ensure safe, easy childbirth.

This deity is also called "Yuna Kojin", who is Kofuku Tenno Shutakushin (home guardian) believed to give people the three treasures of "i shoku jyu" (food, clothing & shelter) as well as to ensure safe, easy childbirth.

This deity is also called 'Yuna Kojin,' who is Kofuku Tenno Shutakushin (home guardian) believed to give people the three treasures of 'i shoku ju' (food, clothing & shelter) as well as to ensure safe, easy childbirth.

sen.j: また、本堂に勝軍地蔵を祀っている。
sen.e: In addition, Shogun Jizo Bosatsu is also enshrined in the main hall of the temple.
In addition, Shogun Jizo Bosatsu is also enshrined in the main hall of the temple.
In addition, Shogun Jizo Bosatsu is also enshrined in the main hall of the temple.

sen.j: 京都泉山七福神の第4番「布袋尊」の札所となっている。
sen.e: On the pilgrim route of Kyoto Senzan Shichifukujin (Seven Deities of Good Luck), Raigo-in is the 4th fudasho (temple that issues amulets) that worships "Hoteison" (pot-bellied god of good fortune).
On the pilgrim route of Kyoto Senzan Shichifukujin (Seven Deities of Good Luck), Raigo-in is the 4th fudasho (temple that issues amulets) that worships "Hoteison" (pot-bellied god of good fortune).
On the pilgrim route of Kyoto Senzan Shichifukujin (Seven Deities of Good Luck), Raigo-in is the 4th fudasho (temple that issues amulets) that worships 'Hoteison' (pot-bellied god of good fortune).

sen.e: Gansui tei garden of the Chisen-kaiyushiki-teien style (a stroke-style garden around a big pond) and the Shinji-ike pond (pond in the shape of a Chinese character, "心" (heart))
